attributes.title: The effects of Interpersonal Closeness on Nonverbal Mimicry during Face-to-Face Interactions

q1.value: The Effects of Interpersonal Closeness on Nonverbal Mimicry during Face-to-Face Interactions

q3.value: The perception of closeness with our interaction partner effects the quality of our interactions. The value of interpersonal closeness is evident from studies that link closeness to our willingness to divulge personal or sensitive information (Dubois, Bonezzi, & De Angelis, 2016; Wiese, Kelley, Cranor, Dabbish, & Zimmerman, 2011). However, little research has been dedicated to identifying ways to increase perceptions of closeness. This could be beneficial in a number of contexts, ranging from business strategies (REF), to forensic investigations (REF). Thus, we highlight the importance of targeting this gap in the literature. Our research aims to do this by exploring the role of nonverbal mimicry in forming and maintaining relationship closeness. Nonverbal mimicry can be described as the imitation of behaviour that partners engage in during an interaction (Tanya, Chartrand, & Van Baaren, 2009). We argue that nonverbal mimicry is a behavioural manifestation of interpersonal closeness, and predict that the enactment of nonverbal mimicry during an interaction will alter feelings of closeness.  The present study aims to address this using motion capture. Our study examines how our perception of closeness with our interaction partner effects how much we mimic their behaviour.

q4.value:
Our study examines how nonverbal mimicry varies between strangers, acquaintances, and romantic partners, which we consider as varying on a closeness continuum from completely overlapping sense of self with other, to no sense of overlapping. We predict that mimicry will be significantly more frequent in the romantic relationship condition and will show a linear decrease from the acquaintances to the strangers condition. 
However, due to the ambiguous nature of the familiarity literature, we predict that a quadratic (inverted U) relationship is possible, with the acquaintances condition showing the highest level of mimicry compared to the strangers and romantic partners conditions. 
This study utilises the IOS scale as a manipulation check, to ensure that the three relationship conditions vary significantly in perceptions of closeness.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will adopt an independent group design, with 3 ‘relationship’ conditions (Stranger vs. Acquaintance vs. Relationship). Participants will interact over a riddle-solving task. Our interest is whether or not the degree of mimicry differs across the three relationship conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants in the strangers and romantic partners condition will be recruited via word-of-mouth, and advertised via social media platforms. Participants in the acquaintances condition will be recruited through the experimenter asking for volunteers following a class (to avoid participants only pairing with close friends in class).

q13.value: A statistical power analysis was performed for sample size estimation, based on data from Van Der Zee et al., (2018) (N=98), looking at non-verbal mimicry and lie difficulty. The effect size (ES) in this study was r = .24, considered to be medium using Cohen's (1988) criteria. With an alpha = .05 and power = 0.80, the projected sample size needed (based on calculations using GPower 3.1) to achieve this effect size  is exactly 100. Thus, we propose to collect data from 102 participants (34 in each cell), which is adequate for the main objective of this study. Participants will be students, romantic partners and acquaintances of the students, as well as non-students that are willing to take part, ages 18 and above.

question.value: We will be manipulating the amount of closeness in each condition, by sampling different relationship types; strangers, acquaintances, and romantic partners. Closeness will be measured using the Inclusion of the Other in the Self (IOS) scale (Aron et al., 1992). This is a single-item, pictorial measure whereby participants are presented with seven pairs of circles ranging from not touching at all to almost entirely overlapping. Participants select the pair that best describes their relationship with their fellow participant. Although brief, the IOS Scale has been consistently rated a  psychologically meaningful and highly reliable measure of the subjective closeness of relationships (Gächter, Starmer, & Tufano, 2015).

We captured participants nonverbal movements using XSens MVN motion tracking system, which measures the 3D position of 23 joints via 17 match-box size inertial sensors. We will examine the amount of nonverbal mimicry the occurs between pairs during the interaction. We predict that mimicry will be significantly more frequent in the romantic relationship condition and will show a linear decrease from the acquaintances to the strangers condition.
A one way ANOVA Design (strangers vs. acquaintances vs. romantic partners).

attributes.title: Knowledge and perceptions of coronavirus disease 2019 among the general public in the United States and the United Kingdom

q1.value: Knowledge and perceptions of coronavirus disease 2019 among the general public in the United States and the United Kingdom

q3.value: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) may spread to become a generalized epidemic in the United States and the United Kingdom. How the general public will behave in such a generalized epidemic is likely to have an important influence on the epidemic's course. To inform public health efforts, this study, therefore, aims to determine what people know about COVID-19 and which misperceptions they have about the virus, the illness it causes, and the current state of the epidemic.

q4.value: This is a descriptive study that is not primarily hypothesis-driven. However, I hypothesize that the general public in the United States and the United Kingdom has several important misperceptions regarding how to prevent an infection with COVID-19, how to prevent onward transmission of the virus, symptoms of the illness caused by COVID-19, and the current state of the epidemic (e.g., number of people infected and the probability that a COVID-19 infection is fatal).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a cross-sectional online survey. The study population is adults residing in the United States or the United Kingdom who are registered with Prolific (https://www.prolific.co) to participate in research in return for a small payment. Prolific offers researchers to select for them a sample that is representative by age, sex, and ethnicity for each the United States and the United Kingdom population. I will use this feature to send an online questionnaire built using Qualtrics software to 1,500 adults in the United States and 1,000 adults in the United Kingdom. The questionnaire will take approximately 10 minutes to complete. Questions will cover: i) the perceived seriousness of a COVID-19 infection; ii) the characteristics of the population groups who are most at risk of dying from a COVID-19 infection; iii) the current state of the epidemic in the United States and the United Kingdom; iv) ways of preventing an infection with COVID-19; v) signs and symptoms of the illness caused by COVID-19; vi) recommended healthcare-seeking behavior; vii) causes of the epidemic; and viii) individuals' basic sociodemographic characteristics.

q9.value: This is not a randomized study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This study is a cross-sectional online survey. The study population is adults residing in the United States or the United Kingdom who are registered with Prolific (https://www.prolific.co) to participate in research in return for a small payment. Prolific offers researchers to select for them a sample that is representative by age, sex, and ethnicity for each the United States and the United Kingdom population. I will use this feature to send an online questionnaire built using Qualtrics software to 1,500 adults in the United States and 1,000 adults in the United Kingdom. The questionnaire will take approximately 10 minutes to complete. Questions will cover: i) the perceived seriousness of a COVID-19 infection; ii) the characteristics of the population groups who are most at risk of dying from a COVID-19 infection; iii) the current state of the epidemic in the United States and the United Kingdom; iv) ways of preventing an infection with COVID-19; v) signs and symptoms of the illness caused by COVID-19; vi) recommended healthcare-seeking behavior; vii) causes of the epidemic; and viii) individuals' basic sociodemographic characteristics. 

The full questionnaire that will be used can be accessed here: https://stanfordmedicine.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ahN5jTAEGpVLC7z

q13.value: The target sample size is 1,500 adults residing in the United States and 1,000 adults residing in the United Kingdom.

q14.value: Because this research is not primarily hypothesis-driven, this study is not powered to test a specific hypothesis. As such, I chose a sample size that will provide reasonably precise estimates for the responses to all questions in the questionnaire.

question.value: The response to each of the questions in the questionnaire (available at: https://stanfordmedicine.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ahN5jTAEGpVLC7z) forms its own variable. Responses will not be merged into composite variables or indices. Exceptions to this are: i) a question on how one can prevent infection with COVID-19, for which I will assess whether respondents identified all correct ways to prevent a COVID-19 infection and count how many incorrect ways a respondent selected; and ii) a question on signs and symptoms of a COVID-19 infection, for which I will assess whether respondents identified all symptoms and signs that are common in a COVID-19 infection and count how many symptoms and signs were selected that are not common in a COVID-19 infection.

Questionnaire responses will not be merged into composite variables or indices. Exceptions to this are: i) a question on how one can prevent infection with COVID-19, for which I will assess whether respondents identified all correct ways to prevent a COVID-19 infection and count how many incorrect ways a respondent selected; and ii) a question on signs and symptoms of a COVID-19 infection, for which I will assess whether respondents identified all symptoms and signs that are common in a COVID-19 infection and count how many symptoms and signs were selected that are not common in a COVID-19 infection.

I will use simple descriptive statistics (percent for binary and categorical variables, and mean, median, standard deviation, and interquartile range for continuous variables) to summarize the responses to each question in the questionnaire. In addition, I will test whether responses vary by individuals' sociodemographic characteristics. For binary outcome variables, I will use Poisson regression with heteroskedasticity-robust standard errors. For count outcomes, I will use ordinary least squares or Poisson regression depending on the empirical distribution of the variable (but show results from both model types). I will run regressions both as univariable regressions (i.e., with just one sociodemographic variable as predictor) and multivariable regression (i.e., with all sociodemographic variables as predictors).

q20.value: In primary analyses, age will be categorized into ten-year age groups.

q21.value: A p-value <0.05 will be used to indicate statistical significance. Two-tailed tests will be used throughout the analysis. I will not adjust for multiple hypothesis testing because this research is not primarily hypothesis-driven.

q22.value: Respondents who take less than two minutes in total to fill out the questionnaire will be excluded from the analysis based on the rationale that this would indicate random clicking. In addition, I will exclude those who do not complete the entire questionnaire.

q23.value: The questionnaire is built such a response is required to move to the next question. I, therefore, do not expect any missing data. Respondents who abort the questionnaire prior to reaching the end of the questionnaire will be excluded from the analysis.

summary.value:
Preregistration: Does Smiling Predict Attachment?
Purpose
	The purpose of this study is to discover if there is a correlation about people’s attachment and their likeability to a stranger when the stranger is smiling or making a neutral face. It is the subject’s attachment to their mother and/or father and whether they like or do not like a person when they see a picture of a stranger smiling or making a neutral face. 
Participants
This study will randomly select 100 students who are legal adults, 18 and older. Participants will be recruited on Southern Methodist University’s campus. They will be approached by one of the five researchers on campus, whether the participant is walking to class or eating in the dining halls. Data will only be discarded when participants are under 18 because this study focuses on adults, not minors. As a note, this study will be collecting fewer than 180 subjects. Because of this small sample size, it is a limitation to generalize and apply this study to our subjects of interest. 
Measures
	The variables observed will be age through numeric free responses and gender through a nominal scale. To collect demographic information, another variable will use a free response to answer the state and country they spent most of their childhood. After collecting general information, other variables observed are the subject’s relationship to each of their parents on an 5-item ordinal scale from strong to distant relationship. Subjects with only one parent and students without parents will be included to observe if there is no attachment from a parent can correlate with one’s responses to seeing a smiling or neutral face. 
Procedure
This study will begin by obtaining two photos of a stranger; one photo with the stranger making a neutral face and the other with the same stranger smiling. Researchers in this group will randomly approach each participant on SMU’s campus. The researcher will ask the participant the same question: Would you mind taking a quick survey because it will only take 5 minutes? There will be no discussion about the premises of the study until the participant completes the survey. If the participant says yes, the researcher will use a random number generator on their devices prior to distributing the survey to determine whether the participant will see the neutral face or smiling face from the stranger’s picture. Using a nominal scale, a randomly selected even number = smiling face and odd number = tails. Once the participant has been assigned to the treatment of either seeing the smiling face or neutral face. Before completing these questions, the participant will see one of the facial reactions from the stranger’s picture. After seeing one of the stranger’s smiling or neutral face, the participant will then ask if they like the stranger or not. These questions will ask their name, age, gender, state and country they grew up, their attachment to their mother and/or father. 
Analyses and Expected Results
This study’s results hope to find a correlation between an adult’s liking to a stranger when they are presented either a smiling face or neutral face and its correlation to their attachment to their mother and/or father. In this study, it is expected to see a strong, positive correlation between a strong parental attachment and liking to a stranger’s photo and a weaker correlation between a weak or no parental attachment and liking to a stranger’s photo. 
Hypotheses
If the participant has a moderately strong attachment with their mother and/or father, then it can correlate with their likeability when seeing a neutral or smiling face. If the participant has a strong attachment to their mother and/or father and sees a smiling or neutral face, they will like the stranger in the photo. If the participant has a moderate,weak, or no relationship with their mother and/or father and sees a neutral face, they will not like the stranger in the photo.

attributes.title: Prevalence of signs and symptoms of bruxism in children: A systematic review
attributes.description: Sleep bruxism signs and symptoms differ according to the patient and could include abnormal tooth wear, tongue indentations, line alba along the biting plane, hypertrophy of masseter muscles, grinding of teeth accompanied by a characteristic sound, pain in the masticatory and/or cervical muscles, pain in temporomandibular joint and headache. The prevalence of SB in children presents a very high variability and is reported to be between 5.9% and 49.6%. It is considered a multifactorial behavior, so it is important to know which signs and symptoms are the most prevalent and frequent of sleep bruxism. This would be important for the clinician and the parents, as they could assist in the suspicion and identification of sleep bruxism. The research question: Investigate the prevalence of signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism in children.

q1.value: Prevalence of signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism in children: A systematic review

q2.value: Josiane Pezzini Soares, Juliana Moro, Carla Massignan, Júnia Serra-Negra, Lucianne Cople Maia, Michele Bolan

q3.value: Sleep bruxism signs and symptoms differ according to the patient and could include abnormal tooth wear, tongue indentations, line alba along the biting plane, hypertrophy of masseter muscles, grinding of teeth accompanied by a characteristic sound, pain in the masticatory and/or cervical muscles, pain in temporomandibular joint and headache. The prevalence of SB in children presents a very high variability and is reported to be between 5.9% and 49.6%. It is considered a multifactorial behavior, so it is important to know which signs and symptoms are the most prevalent and frequent sleep bruxism. This would be important for the clinician and the parents, as they could assist in the suspicion and identification of sleep bruxism. The research question: Investigate the prevalence of signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism in children.

q4.value: Signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism are common and prevalent in children

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This systematic review will include descriptive studies that evaluated signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Explanation of existing data available in the literature regarding the subject:
Clin Oral Investig. 2017 Dec;21(9):2789-2799. doi: 10.1007/s00784-017-2081-7. Epub 2017 Feb 17.
Association between signs and symptoms of bruxism and presence of tori: a systematic review.
Bertazzo-Silveira E1, Stuginski-Barbosa J2, Porporatti AL3, Dick B4, Flores-Mir C5, Manfredini D6, De Luca Canto G7,5.

Justify: Did not evaluate the signs and symptoms of bruxism in children

question.value: Two independent reviewers (1R and 2R) will collect data from the selected articles. Once selected, they will crosscheck the retrieved information with the third reviewer (3R). Any disagreement will be discussed between them. Descriptive data from questionnaires about children’s signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism. Data from questionnaires or clinical examinations of signs and symptoms will be used for qualitative analysis. If quantitative synthesis is appropriate, a meta-analysis will be performed. Heterogeneity will be assessed using the Cochran Q test; I2 statistics and prediction range.

q13.value: Descriptive data from questionnaires about children’s signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism. Data from questionnaires or clinical examinations of signs and symptoms will be used for qualitative analysis.

question.value: Frequency and percentage
If quantitative synthesis is appropriate, a meta-analysis will be performed. Heterogeneity will be assessed using the Cochran Q test; I2 statistics and prediction range.

registration_responses.q1: Prevalence of signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism in children: A systematic review
registration_responses.q2: Josiane Pezzini Soares, Juliana Moro, Carla Massignan, Júnia Serra-Negra, Lucianne Cople Maia, Michele Bolan
registration_responses.q3: Sleep bruxism signs and symptoms differ according to the patient and could include abnormal tooth wear, tongue indentations, line alba along the biting plane, hypertrophy of masseter muscles, grinding of teeth accompanied by a characteristic sound, pain in the masticatory and/or cervical muscles, pain in temporomandibular joint and headache. The prevalence of SB in children presents a very high variability and is reported to be between 5.9% and 49.6%. It is considered a multifactorial behavior, so it is important to know which signs and symptoms are the most prevalent and frequent sleep bruxism. This would be important for the clinician and the parents, as they could assist in the suspicion and identification of sleep bruxism. The research question: Investigate the prevalence of signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism in children.
registration_responses.q4: Signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism are common and prevalent in children
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11:
Explanation of existing data available in the literature regarding the subject:
Clin Oral Investig. 2017 Dec;21(9):2789-2799. doi: 10.1007/s00784-017-2081-7. Epub 2017 Feb 17.
Association between signs and symptoms of bruxism and presence of tori: a systematic review.
Bertazzo-Silveira E1, Stuginski-Barbosa J2, Porporatti AL3, Dick B4, Flores-Mir C5, Manfredini D6, De Luca Canto G7,5.

Justify: Did not evaluate the signs and symptoms of bruxism in children

registration_responses.q8.question: This systematic review will include descriptive studies that evaluated signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism

Once selected, they will crosscheck the retrieved information with the third reviewer (3R). Any disagreement will be discussed between them. Descriptive data from questionnaires about children’s signs and symptoms of sleep bruxism. Data from questionnaires or clinical examinations of signs and symptoms will be used for qualitative analysis. If quantitative synthesis is appropriate, a meta-analysis will be performed. Heterogeneity will be assessed using the Cochran Q test; I2 statistics and prediction range.

attributes.title: The Influence of Guilt and Outrage on Pro-Environmental Behaviour

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The Influence of Guilt and Outrage on Pro-Environmental Behaviour

other.value: We will ask participants about the reasons for their prize-draw choice, for exploratory purposes.

sample.value: For this 3x2 between subjects design, a sample size of N = 244 is required to detect a small to medium effect size (f =.20, alpha error prob = .05 and power = 0.8)

dependent.value: Participants' pro-environmental behaviour intentions will be assessed using two six-item scales. One scale assesses pro-environmental behaviour intentions that focus on one's own responsibility (congruent with guilt) and the other assesses intentions that focus on others' responsibility (e.g. government policies; congruent with outrage). They will also be given a survey to assess their preferences for a range of products: some eco-friendly, and some non eco-friendly. Additionally, participants will be able to enter into a prize draw where they have a choice of an eco-friendly hamper or an amazon voucher.

conditions.value: A 3 (recalled emotion: guilt, outrage, neutral) x 2 (environmental text condition: phrased as own responsibility, phrased as others' responsibility) between subjects design will be used. Participants will be randomly assigned an emotion to recall: either guilt, or outrage, or an emotionally neutral control condition. Then participants will be presented with a text about environmental damages that either relates to guilt or to outrage.

hypothesis.value: This study will investigate the influence of guilt and outrage on pro-environmental engagement.  Participants will be required to recall an emotion (guilt, outrage, or emotionally neutral control) and then will be shown a text about environmental damage that either relates to guilt or outrage. Subsequently their pro-environmental engagement will be assessed. We predict that the guilt and outrage conditions will lead to greater pro-environmental engagement than the control condition. We predict that there will be differences in pro-environmental engagement between those in the guilt and outrage conditions.  We also predict that there will be differences in pro-environmental engagement between those who are shown environmental texts that relate the emotion they recalled and those who are shown environmental texts that do not relate to the emotion they recalled.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

One scale assesses pro-environmental behaviour intentions that focus on one's own responsibility (congruent with guilt) and the other assesses intentions that focus on others' responsibility (e.g. government policies; congruent with outrage). They will also be given a survey to assess their preferences for a range of products: some eco-friendly, and some non eco-friendly. Additionally, participants will be able to enter into a prize draw where they have a choice of an eco-friendly hamper or an amazon voucher.
registration_responses.conditions: A 3 (recalled emotion: guilt, outrage, neutral) x 2 (environmental text condition: phrased as own responsibility, phrased as others' responsibility) between subjects design will be used. Participants will be randomly assigned an emotion to recall: either guilt, or outrage, or an emotionally neutral control condition. Then participants will be presented with a text about environmental damages that either relates to guilt or to outrage.
registration_responses.hypothesis: This study will investigate the influence of guilt and outrage on pro-environmental engagement.  Participants will be required to recall an emotion (guilt, outrage, or emotionally neutral control) and then will be shown a text about environmental damage that either relates to guilt or outrage. Subsequently their pro-environmental engagement will be assessed. We predict that the guilt and outrage conditions will lead to greater pro-environmental engagement than the control condition. We predict that there will be differences in pro-environmental engagement between those in the guilt and outrage conditions.  We also predict that there will be differences in pro-environmental engagement between those who are shown environmental texts that relate the emotion they recalled and those who are shown environmental texts that do not relate to the emotion they recalled.

attributes.title: Organ donation registration defaults, autonomy and effective decision making

q1.value: Organ donation registration defaults, autonomy and effective decision making

q2.value: Esther Steenaart, Rik Crutzen, Nanne (N.K.) de Vries

q3.value:
Countries with an opt-out system, as opposed to an opt-in system in which people have to give explicit consent for organ donation, usually have higher donation rates. Defaults can make people choose the desired behavior, which – from a public health point of view – could be very useful in the context of organ donation. However, the decision itself cannot be regarded as the only outcome, because, especially in the context of healthcare, decisions are often value-laden and can therefore not be right or wrong. It is therefore important to also gain inside in the decision-making process and how people experience that.
Differences between opt-in and opt-out systems regarding organ donation have been studied before. In the Netherlands, where the current study is carried out, a new system will be introduced in July 2020; the so called ‘no objection system’. As this is a new system, we cannot predict what the effects of this will be on how people make a decision about organ donation. It is unknown how this holds up against a traditional opt-in or opt-out system. 
The research questions (RQ) in the study at hand are:
-	1. How are different registration systems associated with autonomy and effective decision making?
-	2. Are these associations different when an option is preselected in the questionnaire? 
-	3. Are autonomy and effective decision making associated?

q4.value:
Regarding RQ1:
-	We hypothesize that people have lower levels of autonomy satisfaction when presented with an opt-out system and have higher levels of frustration about unmet needs, compared to an opt-in system. 
-	We hypothesize that people’s decision making is less effective when being presented with an opt-out system. 
Regarding RQ2:
-	We hypothesize that a preselected option is associated with lower levels of autonomy and higher levels of frustration, and also lower levels of effective decision making. However, this relationship is expected to be different for the different registration systems, as those associations are expected to be stronger for an opt-out system compared to an opt-in system. 
Regarding RQ3:
-	We hypothesize that lower autonomy satisfaction and higher levels of frustration about unmet needs, is associated with lower levels of effective decision making regarding organ donation. 
In general, regarding the new Dutch ‘no-objection’ system, we have not formulated hypotheses and this study is exploratory in nature. While it is sometimes presented as the optimum balance between an opt-in and an opt-out system (and therefore might also score somewhere between the opt-in and opt-out system in terms of levels of autonomy, frustration, and effective decision making), very little is known about the possible impact of this new system on autonomy, frustration, and effective decision making.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A between-subjects experimental design, in which participants are presented with a description of either an opt-in system, an opt-out system or a no objection system, with either a preselected option or not. So in total there will be six conditions, varying in two factors (3x2; system x preselection). After a short description, participants will be asked to make a decision about their organs under this system (being a hypothetical decision, not an actual registration – a so-called vignette study). If participants are randomized into a condition with a preselected option, they have the freedom to change this option. After, they will answer questions related to their feelings of autonomy satisfaction, frustration and effective decision making. 
The questionnaire will be conducted online and participants will be recruited through the Flycatcher panel (more information will follow in data collection procedures).

q9.value: Participants in this study are part of the Flycatcher panel. They receive an e-mail as an invitation to participate in this particular study. When they decide to participate, they will then be randomly assigned to one of the six conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be asked to fill out the online questionnaire. The sample will be a representative sample of the general Dutch population above the age of 18, including people from different regions, different sexes and different age categories. 
They will be recruited through the Flycatcher panel. Flycatcher is a consumer panel, which started in 2000 as a spin-off of Maastricht University. This panel complies with strict quality requirements for research and submits itself to audits by an independent auditing committee. These requirements were laid down in the ISO 20252 standard for market research and opinion polls and ISO 26362 for research panels. As information and data constitute the core of their business, they’ve also obtained ISO 27001 certification, the internationally recognized standard for information security. 
People voluntarily register as panel members and sign a generic informed consent when they register. They get invited to participate in research over e-mail on a regular basis. They get an e-mail when new questionnaires are available for them. They always have the choice whether they would like to participate or not. Every year, panel members are asked to update their demographic information. We will receive the data with regard to the measured variables specified below as well as demographic information of the people who participated. The data we receive, will be non-traceable.
Flycatcher makes use of a reward system, in which participants receive points when filling out a questionnaire, which they can later use to get a voucher or donate the money to charity. As the questionnaire is short, they will receive a small number of points.

q13.value: In total, there will be 1290 people participating in the study, which will be randomized across six conditions (i.e., approximately 215 participants per condition).

q14.value: A sample size calculation was done using G*Power. A total number of 1290 participants is required, based on a small effect size (Cohen’s f: 0.1), a power of 0.8 and an alpha of 0.05.

q15.value: Flycatcher will recruit 1290 participants, who will be randomly assigned to a condition when agreeing to participate. When the total number of participants is achieved, the questionnaire will close and cannot be completed anymore by panel members.

question.value: Registration system (opt-in, opt-out, or no objection) and preselection of the default option (yes, no) are the variables that are manipulated by means of the description of the registration system and the default option in that system being preselected or not. This results in 6 conditions in total (3x2; registration system x preselection).

All conditions will receive the same questions. The following variables are measured:
-	Demographic information; not separately measured in this questionnaire. Participants fill this out when they subscribe to the panel and are asked to update this information at least once a year. 
-	Registration decision (I do nothing/I actively register as a donor/I actively register as a non-donor)
-	Autonomy satisfaction and autonomy frustration (four questions in total, derived from the Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration Scale (BPNSNF). These questions will be answered on a 5-point-likert scale (totally disagree-totally agree).
-	Effective decision making (4 questions in total derived from the Decisional Conflict Scale (DCS). These questions will be answered on a 5-point-likert scale (totally disagree-totally agree).
The questionnaire can be found in the supplementary materials.

The autonomy satisfaction and frustration questions will be combined into a mean score on that scale, as well as the effective decision making questions. This will be done by dividing the total score of those items by four.

Descriptive analyses for all variables. 
-	RQ 1. How are different registration systems associated with autonomy and effective decision making?
o	Autonomy:
	One-way ANOVA to detect differences in autonomy for different registration systems (opt-in vs opt-out vs no-objection, regardless of default)
o	Effective decision making 
	One-way ANOVA to detect differences in effective decision making for different registration systems (opt-in vs opt-out vs no-objection, regardless of default)
-	RQ 2. Are these associations different when an option is preselected in the questionnaire? 
o	Autonomy:
	Two-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) to test for interaction effects between the default and registration system on autonomy 
	If there is no interaction effect:
•	One-way ANOVA to detect differences in autonomy for different defaults (default vs no default, regardless of registration system) 
	If there is an interaction effect:
•	One-way ANOVA to detect differences in autonomy for different registration systems and defaults (opt-in default vs op-in no default vs opt-out default vs opt-out no default vs no-objection default vs no-objection no default) 
o	Effective decision making 
	The same procedure will be applied to effective decision making (with effective decision making as the outcome instead of autonomy). 
-	RQ 3. Are autonomy and effective decision making associated? 
o	Correlations

q21.value: We will make use of a p-value of 0.05. We will use a Benjamini-Hochberg correction to adjust for multiple comparisons.

registration_responses.q2: Esther Steenaart, Rik Crutzen, Nanne (N.K.) de Vries

attributes.title: The effects of combined cognitive and exercise training interventions on cognition in older adults with and without cognitive impairment
attributes.description: The purpose of this review is to systematically review the literature for evidence of a treatment effect from combined cognitive and exercise (training on cognition in older adults with and without cognitive impairment.

q1.value: The effects of combined cognitive and exercise training interventions on cognition in older adults with and without cognitive impairment

q2.value: Associate Professor Justin Keogh, Mia Schaumberg, Samantha Fien, Fiona Barnett, Rodrigo Ramirez-Campillo, Marion Gray

q3.value: There is emerging evidence to suggest that exercise can improve cognitive function in older adults, but it is unclear whether such effects are affected by the level of cognitive demand of the exercise program or the baseline cognitive function of the older adult.  Therefore, this systematic review will look to examine the effects of combined cognitive and exercise training interventions on cognition in older adults with and without cognitive impairment.

q4.value: Combined cognitive and exercise training will improve a variety of cognitive measures in older adults, with the improvement in cognitive function perhaps mediated by the baseline level of cognition and type of exercise prescription.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Not applicable as this is a systematic review/meta-analysis

question.value: This study is a systematic review and potential meta-analysis that seeks to review the current peer-reviewed literature to quantify the effects of combined cognitive and exercise training interventions on cognitive outcomes in older adults, with or without cognitive impairment.  The first aim of the systematic review will be to improve our understanding of whether combined cognitive and physical exercise training can improve cognition in older adults, and if this is influenced by aspects of the exercise prescription.  A secondary aim will be to examine whether these exercise-related improvements in cognitive function are influenced by the baseline level of cognitive function of the older adult.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: As a systematic review, we will be accessing the summary data reported in the eligible papers.

question.value:
Data will be extracted according to the PRISMA guidelines. The screening process to be used in the search will involve a hierarchy of assessments that begin by identifying relevant journal titles (with duplicates removed), followed by the abstract and full article review.  Final decision on the eligibility of the article will be based off the inclusion and exclusion criteria. 
Current list of databases 
•	CINAHL
•	Medline 
•	PsycINFO
•	EMBASE 
•	Cochrane Library 
•	Pubmed 
•	Web of Science  
Search terms 
Each data base contained different ways here on how to present the search terms, PubMed version was the following: 
Mesh Terms 
“aged” 
“aged, 80 and over”
“mild cognitive impairment” 
“exercise”
“physical activity”
“resistance training”
“control group”
“attention”
“reaction time”
“randomized controlled trial” 
 
Key search terms 
 “endurance training” 
“memory” 
“cognit*” 
 “older adults” 
 “cognitive dysfunction” 
“dual-task” 
“multi-modal” 
“aerobic training”
“cognitive training”  
“cognitive-motor training”
“mental training”  
“memory training” 
“usual care”
“global cognition” 
“cognitive domain” 
‘randomised controlled trial” 
 “controlled trial” 
“RCT”
“CT” 
 
 
((((((("aged"[MeSH Terms] OR "aged, 80 and over"[MeSH Terms]) OR "cognitive dysfunction"[MeSH Terms]) OR "older adults"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive dysfunction"[All Fields]) AND (((((((((("exercise"[MeSH Terms] OR "exercise"[MeSH Terms]) OR "resistance training"[MeSH Terms]) OR "dual-task"[All Fields]) OR "multi-modal"[All Fields]) OR "aerobic training"[All Fields]) OR "endurance training"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive training"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive-motor training"[All Fields]) OR "mental training"[All Fields]) OR "memory training"[All Fields])) AND ("control groups"[MeSH Terms] OR "usual care"[All Fields])) AND ((((("attention"[MeSH Terms] OR "reaction time"[MeSH Terms]) OR "memory"[All Fields]) OR "global cognition"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive domain"[All Fields]) OR "cognit*"[All Fields])) AND (((("randomized controlled trials as topic"[MeSH Terms] OR "randomised controlled trial"[All Fields]) OR "controlled trial"[All Fields]) OR "RCT"[All Fields]) OR "CT"[All Fields]) 

Inclusion criteria 
(1) older adults (65 and over) with cognitive impairment/decline but no mental or neurological dis-orders, such as stroke or major depression or dementia
(2) combined cognitive and exercise training with a non-combined or control comparator 
(3) randomized controlled trial (RCT) or controlled trial (CT)
(4) A measure of global cognition (MMSE, ACE-R, MOCA, ADAS-COG) as primary or secondary outcomes
(5) Free terms for exercise (‘aerobic exercise’, ‘aerobic training’, ‘resistance exercise’, ‘resistance training’, ‘walk*’, ‘jog*’, ‘swim*’, ‘run*’, ‘cycl*’, ‘low intensity exercise’, ‘low intensity training’, ‘moderate intensity exercise’, ‘moderate intensity training’, ‘moderate intensity continuous training’, ‘high intensity exercise’, ‘high intensity training’, ‘high-intensity interval training’, ‘sprint interval training’, ‘sprint training’, ‘sprint exercise’) were used in AND-combination
 
Exclusion criteria 
(1) non-intervention studies; 
(2) theoretical articles or descriptions of treatment approaches; 
(3) review articles; 
(4) unpublished studies, abstracts or dissertations; 
(5) articles with-out adequate specification of interventions; 
(6) non-peer reviewed articles and book chapters; 
(7) non-English language articles;
(8) Multicomponent intervention studies which did not distinguish the contribution of combined cognitive and physical exercise component on the effects were also excluded.

q13.value: As a systematic review, sample size is not applicable.

question.value: Not applicable

Main outcomes
A measure of global cognition (MMSE, ACE-R, MOCA, ADAS-COG) as primary or secondary outcomes will be assessed. 

Additional outcomes: 
Measures assessing individual cognitive domains, including attention, reaction time, processing speed, executive control, emotion recognition, spatial and/or verbal learning and memory as determined by neuropsychological testing.
If possible, a meta-analysis will be performed on the data.

Two members of the research team will independently review each title and abstract identified by the search strategy and full text, where appropriate. Any differences of opinion between the two reviewers about the eligibility of the particular study will be discussed, and a third senior member of the research team consulted if this difference cannot be resolved. Data from the eligible studies will be extracted using a standardised data extraction sheet. Extracted data will include: sample size, sample characteristics (e.g. age, sex, physical
function, cognitive function, comorbidities), setting (e.g. community dwelling or residential aged care), Intervention details (type of motor-cognitive exercise performed, trial duration, frequency and other measures of exercise dose, comparator group), outcomes and assessment instruments, baseline and retest values and adverse events. Two members of the research team will independently extract these forms of data. Where there is missing data, a request will be sent to the study authors.
The review authors will independently assess the risk of bias using the PEDRo scale. each of the reviewers will rate the eligible articles on each of the 11 items of the scale and provide a total score between 0 to 11 for each article. Any disagreements between reviewers scores will be identified, with the two review authors discussing their differences before reaching an agreement. If such agreement can't be obtained, a third senior reviewer will be consulted so that a consensus can be reached. Information on the risk of bias will be used for inclusion into any meta-analysis and discussion of the results of these papers, whereby greater
emphasis will be provided on those studies with a low risk of bias.
Findings from this systematic review will initially be presented using a narrative synthesis approach around each of the cognitive domains, in accordance with the PRISMA guidelines. For studies that included similar outcome measures, results will be pooled in order to perform a random effects meta-analysis. We will conduct separate analyses for different cognitive domains if adequate studies have been identified. The Qstatistic and I² test will be used to examine the heterogeneity among all studies. We will conduct a sensitivity analyses on study quality, intervention component design and for comparator group (negative compared to passive).

q21.value: If a meta-analysis can be performed, standardised weighted mean differences or weighted mean differences will be calculated where applicable.

q23.value: Where there is missing data, a request will be sent to the study authors to provide any missing data.

registration_responses.q1: The effects of combined cognitive and exercise training interventions on cognition in older adults with and without cognitive impairment
registration_responses.q2: Associate Professor Justin Keogh, Mia Schaumberg, Samantha Fien, Fiona Barnett, Rodrigo Ramirez-Campillo, Marion Gray
registration_responses.q3: There is emerging evidence to suggest that exercise can improve cognitive function in older adults, but it is unclear whether such effects are affected by the level of cognitive demand of the exercise program or the baseline cognitive function of the older adult.  Therefore, this systematic review will look to examine the effects of combined cognitive and exercise training interventions on cognition in older adults with and without cognitive impairment.
registration_responses.q4: Combined cognitive and exercise training will improve a variety of cognitive measures in older adults, with the improvement in cognitive function perhaps mediated by the baseline level of cognition and type of exercise prescription.
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: Not applicable as this is a systematic review/meta-analysis
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: As a systematic review, we will be accessing the summary data reported in the eligible papers.
registration_responses.q13: As a systematic review, sample size is not applicable.
registration_responses.q21: If a meta-analysis can be performed, standardised weighted mean differences or weighted mean differences will be calculated where applicable.
registration_responses.q23: Where there is missing data, a request will be sent to the study authors to provide any missing data.
registration_responses.q8.question: This study is a systematic review and potential meta-analysis that seeks to review the current peer-reviewed literature to quantify the effects of combined cognitive and exercise training interventions on cognitive outcomes in older adults, with or without cognitive impairment.  The first aim of the systematic review will be to improve our understanding of whether combined cognitive and physical exercise training can improve cognition in older adults, and if this is influenced by aspects of the exercise prescription.  A secondary aim will be to examine whether these exercise-related improvements in cognitive function are influenced by the baseline level of cognitive function of the older adult.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data will be extracted according to the PRISMA guidelines. The screening process to be used in the search will involve a hierarchy of assessments that begin by identifying relevant journal titles (with duplicates removed), followed by the abstract and full article review.  Final decision on the eligibility of the article will be based off the inclusion and exclusion criteria. 
Current list of databases 
•	CINAHL
•	Medline 
•	PsycINFO
•	EMBASE 
•	Cochrane Library 
•	Pubmed 
•	Web of Science  
Search terms 
Each data base contained different ways here on how to present the search terms, PubMed version was the following: 
Mesh Terms 
“aged” 
“aged, 80 and over”
“mild cognitive impairment” 
“exercise”
“physical activity”
“resistance training”
“control group”
“attention”
“reaction time”
“randomized controlled trial” 
 
Key search terms 
 “endurance training” 
“memory” 
“cognit*” 
 “older adults” 
 “cognitive dysfunction” 
“dual-task” 
“multi-modal” 
“aerobic training”
“cognitive training”  
“cognitive-motor training”
“mental training”  
“memory training” 
“usual care”
“global cognition” 
“cognitive domain” 
‘randomised controlled trial” 
 “controlled trial” 
“RCT”
“CT” 
 
 
((((((("aged"[MeSH Terms] OR "aged, 80 and over"[MeSH Terms]) OR "cognitive dysfunction"[MeSH Terms]) OR "older adults"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive dysfunction"[All Fields]) AND (((((((((("exercise"[MeSH Terms] OR "exercise"[MeSH Terms]) OR "resistance training"[MeSH Terms]) OR "dual-task"[All Fields]) OR "multi-modal"[All Fields]) OR "aerobic training"[All Fields]) OR "endurance training"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive training"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive-motor training"[All Fields]) OR "mental training"[All Fields]) OR "memory training"[All Fields])) AND ("control groups"[MeSH Terms] OR "usual care"[All Fields])) AND ((((("attention"[MeSH Terms] OR "reaction time"[MeSH Terms]) OR "memory"[All Fields]) OR "global cognition"[All Fields]) OR "cognitive domain"[All Fields]) OR "cognit*"[All Fields])) AND (((("randomized controlled trials as topic"[MeSH Terms] OR "randomised controlled trial"[All Fields]) OR "controlled trial"[All Fields]) OR "RCT"[All Fields]) OR "CT"[All Fields]) 

Inclusion criteria 
(1) older adults (65 and over) with cognitive impairment/decline but no mental or neurological dis-orders, such as stroke or major depression or dementia
(2) combined cognitive and exercise training with a non-combined or control comparator 
(3) randomized controlled trial (RCT) or controlled trial (CT)
(4) A measure of global cognition (MMSE, ACE-R, MOCA, ADAS-COG) as primary or secondary outcomes
(5) Free terms for exercise (‘aerobic exercise’, ‘aerobic training’, ‘resistance exercise’, ‘resistance training’, ‘walk*’, ‘jog*’, ‘swim*’, ‘run*’, ‘cycl*’, ‘low intensity exercise’, ‘low intensity training’, ‘moderate intensity exercise’, ‘moderate intensity training’, ‘moderate intensity continuous training’, ‘high intensity exercise’, ‘high intensity training’, ‘high-intensity interval training’, ‘sprint interval training’, ‘sprint training’, ‘sprint exercise’) were used in AND-combination
 
Exclusion criteria 
(1) non-intervention studies; 
(2) theoretical articles or descriptions of treatment approaches; 
(3) review articles; 
(4) unpublished studies, abstracts or dissertations; 
(5) articles with-out adequate specification of interventions; 
(6) non-peer reviewed articles and book chapters; 
(7) non-English language articles;
(8) Multicomponent intervention studies which did not distinguish the contribution of combined cognitive and physical exercise component on the effects were also excluded.
registration_responses.q16.question: Not applicable
registration_responses.q17.question:
Main outcomes
A measure of global cognition (MMSE, ACE-R, MOCA, ADAS-COG) as primary or secondary outcomes will be assessed. 

Additional outcomes: 
Measures assessing individual cognitive domains, including attention, reaction time, processing speed, executive control, emotion recognition, spatial and/or verbal learning and memory as determined by neuropsychological testing.
registration_responses.q18.question: If possible, a meta-analysis will be performed on the data.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Two members of the research team will independently review each title and abstract identified by the search strategy and full text, where appropriate. Any differences of opinion between the two reviewers about the eligibility of the particular study will be discussed, and a third senior member of the research team consulted if this difference cannot be resolved. Data from the eligible studies will be extracted using a standardised data extraction sheet. Extracted data will include: sample size, sample characteristics (e.g. age, sex, physical
function, cognitive function, comorbidities), setting (e.g. community dwelling or residential aged care), Intervention details (type of motor-cognitive exercise performed, trial duration, frequency and other measures of exercise dose, comparator group), outcomes and assessment instruments, baseline and retest values and adverse events. Two members of the research team will independently extract these forms of data. Where there is missing data, a request will be sent to the study authors.
The review authors will independently assess the risk of bias using the PEDRo scale. each of the reviewers will rate the eligible articles on each of the 11 items of the scale and provide a total score between 0 to 11 for each article. Any disagreements between reviewers scores will be identified, with the two review authors discussing their differences before reaching an agreement. If such agreement can't be obtained, a third senior reviewer will be consulted so that a consensus can be reached. Information on the risk of bias will be used for inclusion into any meta-analysis and discussion of the results of these papers, whereby greater
emphasis will be provided on those studies with a low risk of bias.
Findings from this systematic review will initially be presented using a narrative synthesis approach around each of the cognitive domains, in accordance with the PRISMA guidelines. For studies that included similar outcome measures, results will be pooled in order to perform a random effects meta-analysis. We will conduct separate analyses for different cognitive domains if adequate studies have been identified. The Qstatistic and I² test will be used to examine the heterogeneity among all studies. We will conduct a sensitivity analyses on study quality, intervention component design and for comparator group (negative compared to passive).

summary.value:
Previous research has found that Black/White and Asian/White multiracial individuals are racially categorized according to hypodescent (Ho, Sidanius, Levin, & Banaji, 2011), or that Multiracial individuals will be categorized as part of their lower status racial group (Banks & Eberhardt, 1998). In the current study, which is primarily exploratory, we test if other, previously unstudied, multiracial combinations Latino/White, Black/Asian, Black/Latino, and Latino/Asian are also categorized according to hypodescent, or as Latino, Black, Black, and Latino, respectively. If Black/White and Asian/White multiracial individuals are categorized according to hypodescent then other multiracial combinations should theoretically also be categorized according to hypodescent. Additionally, we were interested if hypodescent categorizations influence perceptions of how representative these Multiracial combinations are of the overall Multiracial group. 

Please see attached pdf file for the complete pre-registration for this study.

registration_responses.summary:
Previous research has found that Black/White and Asian/White multiracial individuals are racially categorized according to hypodescent (Ho, Sidanius, Levin, & Banaji, 2011), or that Multiracial individuals will be categorized as part of their lower status racial group (Banks & Eberhardt, 1998). In the current study, which is primarily exploratory, we test if other, previously unstudied, multiracial combinations Latino/White, Black/Asian, Black/Latino, and Latino/Asian are also categorized according to hypodescent, or as Latino, Black, Black, and Latino, respectively. If Black/White and Asian/White multiracial individuals are categorized according to hypodescent then other multiracial combinations should theoretically also be categorized according to hypodescent. Additionally, we were interested if hypodescent categorizations influence perceptions of how representative these Multiracial combinations are of the overall Multiracial group. 

Please see attached pdf file for the complete pre-registration for this study.
